–î—Ä—É–≥–∞—è –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∞ –∏–∑ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–≤—å—é –ø–æ —Ç–∏–Ω—å–∫–æ—Ñ—Ñ/*–î–∞–Ω—ã –¥–≤–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∫–∏. –í—ã–≤–µ—Å—Ç–∏, —Å—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É–µ—Ç –ª–∏ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–µ —Å–æ–ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ –º–µ–∂–¥—É–∏—Ö —Å–∏–º–≤–æ–ª–∞–º–∏, —á—Ç–æ –æ–¥–Ω–∞ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∫–∞ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç—Å—è –≤ –¥—Ä—É–≥—É—é –∏ –ø—Ä–∏ —ç—Ç–æ–º–Ω–∏–∫–∞–∫–∏–µ –¥–≤–µ —Ä–∞–∑–Ω—ã–µ –±—É–∫–≤—ã –Ω–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ö–æ–¥—è—Ç –≤ –æ–¥–Ω—É –∏ —Ç—É –∂–µ.isSimilar("egg","add") => trueisSimilar("bar","foo") => falseisSimilar("kotlin","python") => true*/function isSimilar(str1, str2) {¬†¬†const len1 = str1.length;¬†¬†if (len1 !== str2.length) return false;¬†¬†const values = {};¬†¬†for (let i = 0; i < len1; i++) {¬†¬†¬†¬†const val1 = str1.charCodeAt(i);¬†¬†¬†¬†const val2 = str2.charCodeAt(i);¬†¬†¬†¬†if (values.hasOwnProperty(val1)) {¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†if(values[val1] !== (val1 & val2)) return false;¬†¬†¬†¬†} else if (values.hasOwnProperty(val2)) {¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†if(values[val2] !== (val1 & val2)) return false;¬†¬†¬†¬†} else {¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†values[val1] = val1 & val2;¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†values[val2] = val1 & val2;¬†¬†¬†¬†}¬†¬†}¬†¬†return true;}#it #tinkoff #interview #js ¬†#algorithms

As a farewell, colleagues from the art team placed my avatar into the game we've created and gave it a robo-squad to improve the world. So cute, thanks! ü§©#gamedev #team #gameart #avatar #opentowork #opentobusiness #softwaredevelopment #productdevelopment

Common mistake of techical startup founders in engineering partnership is that they look for a very senior developer, to whom they promise the CTO position.Unfortunately technical seniority doesn't mean people can manage product technologies and people. As a consequences: incorrectly chosen technologies, highly pressured teams with continuous staff turnover, endless refactoring leading to loose a focus from market-readiness product building.There are many frameworks describing engineering career ladders from different point of view: company size, organisational structure, etc. Here is an excellent entry point to read about them all: https://lnkd.in/ek-fmYD4Below is a representation of an average developers' career path. You can see two interesting points: very senior developers don't know management and senior managers (usually but not always) lose practical experience.Should be kept in mind that loosing practical experience may not indicate impossibility of its recovering. Also technical managers can be excellent architects who can drive the whole product without touching code at all. On the other side, management skills (not just soft skills but mostly project and product management) are highly difficult achievable.Finally I would suggest to find somebody in the middle, who have fast and technical mind but may also manage a team (or have enough mind space to learn it).You should definitely think twice on who will be your top management partner when a product rockets up. Too often there is no turning back point.#softwaredevelopment #productdevelopment #startup #leanstartup #founders #career #productmanagement

Software development factory process I created 2 years ago has grown.Small increase on the paper, but significant improvement in scale.Now it includes strategic and tactic levels in addition to operating.Market analysis is the most important part of a business. The usual mistake is to continue analysing it before reaching the MVP stage. In this case idea and vision of a product become continuously changing, which negatively affect goals reachability.After MVP has reached the market, it is time to focus on product metrics and growth opportunities. You can gather data for analysis from:- customer journey map;- customer development;- customer support requests;- UX analysis;- NPS and feedbacks.Remember, when you actively look at competitors, don't be mistaken: you see at ready-to-use solutions, not opportunities! By copying another product you stop growth of your's, because that product improves but your's sticks with the features from the past.Also if you find MVP doesn't have a market fit and want to change its idea or implementation, it is a separate product which should be start from the scratch. Continuing of an old MVP development as a new product is another usual mistake: your business model should be obligatorily recalculated. The new one can have the same numbers - it's OK.With this process on the tactic level you only need to prioritise a flow of features which are defining based on the data analysis.P.S. It also a part of my diploma, therefore your likes and comments are highly important and appreciated.#softwaredevelopment #gamedev #business #productdevelopment #leanstartup #businessprocess #businessprocessmanagement

Where does the planning start?Many people think it starts from prioritising tasks, arranging their timelines and assigning executors. Not really.Before you can arrange tasks you need to define them. Before you can define tasks you need to set a goal which will be achieved by executing them. Before you can set a goal properly you need information about benchmarks.In my diploma I describe planning as a process of 6 stages.1. Analysis. At this stage, benchmarks for goals are set, working material is accumulated for calculating planned indicators for achieving goals. Without this stage, the formation of certain, achievable goals is impossible, since there will be no description of the environment and its factors.2. Goal setting. There is a formation of goals with the consolidation of their planned indicators and decisions to achieve them. Goals should be specific and describe the desired end state of the organisation, project, or parts thereof. Decisions describe specific ways to achieve established goals. It is unacceptable for a target to be put into operation without a corresponding solution.3. Structuring. Breaking down decisions to achieve goals into functional tasks, determining their relationships. A lot of work is done together with specialists to decompose the indicated solutions, form a list of requirements and expected restrictions. Since at this stage the specifics of the real conditions of implementation appear, here the threats to the achievement of goals (threats to the fulfilment of tasks) are identified and solutions are formed to mitigate them.4. Prioritisation. Assigning criticality, sequence and timing of functional tasks based on goals and established relationships. At this stage, as well as at the previous one, threats to the achievement of goals are identified and solutions for their prevention and elimination are expanded.5. Monitoring and correction. Monitoring the implementation of functional tasks, progress towards achieving goals and applying solutions to emerging barriers as needed. These parts are intentionally paired, as the adjustment uses an already developed solution that does not require the effort of restructuring and prioritising.6. Report. Registration of final indicators with the analysis of compliance with the target. The final review documents the effectiveness of the analysis, the correctness of the goal setting and the suitability of the objectives set, and the adequacy of the risk management for effective future planning.Since it is a diploma work, it is highly important to me to know your opinion. Please leave a comment whether you agree with the definition or not. Maybe you have a completely opposite opinion, maybe you have additional stages I missed. Any feedback will be appreciated. Simple likes also. ü§ó #softwaredevelopment #productdevelopment #goalsetting #planning #leanmanagement #strategyexecution #mba #mbajourney

Scalable architecture is one of the most important topics for startups. But what do we mean when we say "scalable"?There are two kinds of scalability: vertical and horizontal. In horizontal scaling we improve the number of simultaneous users by increasing the number of working service instances. During the vertical scale we reduce costs by improving application architecture.When a startup is born it does not have too many users, so the most important goal is the shortest time of development. Nobody knows where things finally go, so the software architecture should be as simple as possible. At the same time, it should be ready for fast horizontal scaling. It is the most important stage because this time the technological future of the project is laying. Any mistake now causes time wasting in the future.After a while, the project growths and important topic starts to be the speed of horizontal scaling. During this stage architects don't have time to think and re-engineer the product, because every day the project works in production it loses potential users who could become a customer in case their needs are satisfied. So the focus is on the new features instead of polishing.When most of the first followers' requests are implemented and the project starts to bring an income, it's time to think on cost optimization. In this stage we have enough time but we need all possible money resources to grow further. Architects should think on how to scale the applications vertically. If somebody now wants to say that vertical scaling increases cost, let me remind you that horizontal scaling increases cost much more because of inefficient secondary resources: traffic requires advanced routing, hardware requires electric power, hundreds of server instances require engineer staff.Here is my view of a software architecture for games, which after being implemented once can be scaled horizontally first, then vertically. It utilizes MVC approach and bases on two main controllers: one manages business logic (commands) and other one manages events. Commands modify data, events notify other components about data updates. When a component receives an event, it gets data from models and updates itself accordingly. This architecture enables a seamless update of components, without huge blocking refactoring. Also it does not prevent you from choosing between a single server and microservices approaches - use whatever you like (actually it hardly depends on the number of members in a team), it doesn't matter because components inside will be portable between them.#startpup #softwaredevelopment #softwarearchitecture #scalability #leanstartup

How organisational changes help to assess managers.When an organisational change integrates, people feel discomfort. Almost everyone passes through DABDA (denial - anger - bargaining - depression - acceptance). These are difficult times for teams. And these are great times to review managers.It is near impossible that a human accept all changes with a pleasure. Especially an excellent manager who continuously drives productivity of a team. Such a manager usually have own processes in plans, atop of basic organisational rules. In that case most changes throw their plans away and break the current productivity.If a manager happy with every change and a hour later already communicates changes to teams, let him go. The situation usually means somebody else playing the key role in these teams and do the best to let projects grow. That team player passes through DABDA by himself and helps teams to pass it, too.Good managers cannot ignore DABDA. They pass it in the shortest time instead: a couple of days, a week. After that time they already have adapted plans and only then they are ready to speak to teams.Beware of managers who simply translate goals to the key team players, who really drive projects.#softwaredevelopment #teammanagement #projectmanagement #changemanagement #peoplemanagement #management #change #team #productivity

How to automate the project version bumping without a bump commit?It is one of the first questions developers have after ci/cd automation.Most people like how semantic versioning looks like: 1.0.0, 1.2.3. Unfortunately, usually it requires manual maintenance. In the best case it can be automated at the release stage, when we absolutely sure on API version, features and patches are going to be deployed, also this requires support of commit labeling and strict rules.At the moment our projects use another option to make a version string which looks similar to semantic but more compatible with agile methodology and continuous integrations.It consists of three components:- project age in years- year week number- number of commits on the weekThe method enables to calculate the same version in any programming language. The only condition is an access to the repository history starting from a Monday of the last commit.Tip to whom use Git shallow clones which hide commits older than the last one. Fetching supports unshallowing since a date using "--shallow-since=<date>" option.Algorithim for Git in this case in general looks as shown below:- fetch the shallow clone of a repository- get a date of the top-most commit;- calculate Monday of the gotten date;- unshallow the repository till the Monday date;- calculate the number of commits.#softwaredevelopment #devops #versioning #automation

A solution to everybody who needs to manage team software development work with more than 40 tickets per weekly sprint per project team, tracking several teams simultaneously.Our team has already worked using Kanban approach where all software development stages are separate statuses: from writing a specification for a task till issuing it in a release. To see the whole picture, the project manager has used the BigPicture plugin for Jira. This solution was working greatly before the number of participants had grown beyond twenty. Afterwards daily meetings have started taking an hour and weekly planning longer than it.We've discussed that despite the company starting to be split per department, it is highly important to keep product development team work closely to see the common progress and be involved deeply.Our decision was to keep workflow as easy and standardized as possible. We converted tickets workflow to the simplest form: Backlog, Progress, Review, Done with supporting statuses like Escalated and Canceled. To track the whole path of a task from an idea till a release, instead using department specific statuses we used issue types:- Epic - record, describe and plan an idea;- GD-Spec - write a specification;- Art-Design - create graphical and sound content;- Dev-Arch - describe architectural changes;- Dev-Feature - implement a new functionality;- Dev-Change - update something already implemented;- Dev-Defect - fix something broken;- Dev-Ops - implement IaC changes;- Release - define release and deploy it into the proper environment;- QA-Write - write or change test scenarios;- QA-Execute - execute test scenarios.We have boards per project which show a matrix of department and status, and a special board which shows all Epic tickets per project which helps us to build and track project roadmaps. A highly convenient bonus of using epics is a badge on each ticket on boards showing which idea or feature it implements!Now we discuss the top level roadmap at product manager meetings and our project manager checks exact tasks progress with implementers from top to the bottom of the software development flow. It became easier to use BigPicture too, by grouping tickets per Epic, because task dependencies are only established between epics and tasks in a single epic.https://lnkd.in/etufkFfc#softwaredevelopment #kanban #jira #projectmanagement

When 5-Whys analysis doesn't work and how to make it dealing.I met the five whys analysis 4 years ago and realized it helps products a lot. On the other hand, there are many criticisms on the Internet which say it is too basic a tool to analyse root causes deep enough. I cannot say that reasons for criticism don't make sense but proposed alternatives like fishbone or lovebug diagrams in my opinion are focused much more on theoretical problem solving rather than on practical: they produce too many options for checking which means we have many potential reasons and none real.First of all, let's remember what the five whys analysis is. It is an iterative technique of issue reason exploring which uses an approach of asking "why" for the initial and each next problem until we get to the root cause of the initial one. Sounds simple, doesn't it? Yup, but often people use the method incorrectly.The main reason the method can not work is a try using it by managers instead of expert knowledge keepers. You should understand involved components and know used technologies. The second issue is to stop on a too high level (fifth). The third common reason for method malfunctioning is a mistaken focus on human lacks at the end.Let's consider an example from Wikipedia: https://lnkd.in/edyjKnrnBy reading it we can mistakenly think that the root cause is in people who ignore maintenance. But wait... really? Nope! Analysis shouldn't stop on that reason and should be continued. Like:6. Why? - Because there is no neither scheduler nor indicator of a service requirement.Actually, I would say that the 5th why is wrong and should be replaced by 6th, but I never focus on such small things because the main goal of an analysis is to find a reason, not spend time on beautifications. The main idea is the incompleteness of the original analysis.So my recommendations to be successful in real issue reason and solution findings are:- learn as you go: improve knowledge instead stopping an analysis;- dig as deep as possible: don't stop on the 5th iteration, continue until the minimal unit¬† which can be fixed is reached;- focus on technical reasons and own knowledge, not on people: inattentiveness, forgetfulness and other cute behaviours are human attributes and could be compensated processual or technologically;- proof conclusions by evidence: attach logs, put screenshots, cite conversations with experts;- cooperate with other teams if reasons go outside responsibilities: never say it is not your problem.Finally, the most important recommendation is to finish analysis with a fix. With two fixes actually: immediate and long term. It is good if an immediate fix also works in the long term, but usually it is not so. For example, as an immediate fix we can hide an error but in the long term we need to address it completely: and the analysis will be our best friend in the future to understand how to complete the fix.#softwaredevelopment

Every contract brings a new astonishment. In one case it was a disposition of resources between database, backend and frontend.At the moment of my joining, team has raised number of CPU for the database instance by 2 every 2 weeks. Analysis showed that the reason is in a decision of moving the logic on the database side. When the startup has only test users, it worked fine. With the real traffic, calculations began requiring more and more resources, about 1:10 per user.Rewriting the application to extract the logic to the backend side solved the problem, but I found a similar pattern in backend-frontend logic placement decisions.All conversions and calculations has been planning to be implemented on the backend side, even if they are trivial and require only simple processing, without any additional optimisation possibilities which could not be implemented on the client side due to algorithms complexity or performance considerations. When only input data verification logic is left on the backend side, the application started working like a charm.I drew this pyramid to show scaling possibilities for every stage of request processing :- database is the least scalable and the most expensive resource;- backend is a scalable and a relatively cheap resource;- frontend is the most scalable and a completely gratis resource.Roughly at an average modern web startup, a ratio between them is 1:10:10000 which means one backend should handle at least 1000 clients simultaneously and 1 database instance should handle at least 10 backends. Definitely not vice versa as in the case above, when a ratio is like 10:1:100.For sure this calculation doesn't include other mechanisms of load distribution like caching, read-only database replicas, etc. But if the current ratio is worse, especially with using of additions, it is an occasion to check reasons.#softwaredevelopment #opentowork

Products become more media and less technical. Strategy goes to the level of using existing technologies and providing services for them, with only small percentage left for inventions. As a consequence, there is a gap in how managers see engineering work:- Project management relies on the strategy and assumes software engineering should have enough knowledge.- Strategic roles relies on software engineering knowledge and experience (expertise).In overall, the situation means we have projects with uncertainty even if they are well documented and planned on the paper: the same  idea is achievable in multiple ways so an implementation can be replaced by another, what requires on-the-fly specification changes. It conflicts with the classic project management. Agile methodology steps in and wins. But it means project management has only a transporting and not a mediator function anymore: technical expertise becomes too important for project survival. So we need a new kind of mediator between business and engineers.The answer is the strategic management itself should play the mediator role. How? By introducing the early begin and the early feedback terms. It means, instead of final specification formation before the work begins, we need already to start creating tasks and get the first feedback from engineers before the planning stage finishes. This allows us to be in sync with our engineering team abilities and choose a solution which we're sure can be implemented. Really. Nowadays a business is much more about storytelling rather than about inventing anything, and teams should do the best to let tales become alive.The same approach works at the end of the execution stage. Before a team reports about completion, we need to start measuring of what we have at that time (near the end). Because 2 stable working features are much important than 3 or more but in an unstable product: instability breaks the magic of our tale told to customers.Good process should be applicable on different levels of scaling. This is true here. If we give engineers time to do a research before deep work, this increases a chance of successful feature implementation significantly. And early result reporting allows to sync the final solution with an initial vision.#OpenToWork #SoftwareDevelopment

To make it not seem so easy and fabulous, we want to remind you of one more thing - the stages of selection for employment.‚†Ä1. Screening of resumes2. Phone interview with HR3. Interview with a team leader or project manager4. Interview for job suitability, here they check your hard skills5. Interview for evaluation of compliance with company values6. Stage of discussing conditions and preparing an offer‚†ÄBe 100% ready for each stage, because your future will depend on each of them.On average all stages of selection take 1.5 - 2 months, so do not worry if the employer does not give feedback in 3 days.‚†ÄAlso, remember that our career specialist will help you prepare for each stage! üòéinstagram: ADABSTAR  #job #career #adabstar #interview #startup

Having decided on the country of your dreams, remember the main thing when applying for employment:‚†Ä1Ô∏è‚É£It is important to prepare your resume:‚†Ä‚Äî What is the name of your position in a particular country;‚Äî A competent description of your duties;‚Äî What soft and hard skills do you have;‚Äî Do not forget to use active verbs when writing a resume;‚†Ä2Ô∏è‚É£Preparing for the interview:‚†Ä‚Äî Build answers using the STAR method;‚Äî Prepare for a behavioral interview and form your career development story;‚Äî Be aware of cultural differences;‚Äî Smile and generally keep a positive attitude in communication;‚Äî Prepare questions about the company;‚†Ä3Ô∏è‚É£And to increase the chances of getting an offer quickly:‚†Ä‚Äî Search by the most relevant experience and industry;‚Äî Make a resume yourself or with the help of our specialists and prepare for an interview;‚Äî Do not forget about places with a smaller flow of emigrants at the moment;‚Äî Use personal networking;‚Äî Sometimes a job search through recruitment agencies of a certain country is good;‚†ÄAsk for help from our specialists and discover all the doors of career development! üòåinstagram: @adabstar #recruitment #experience #adabstar #cv #interview #job #resume #offer #startup

Turning to career specialists, study in advance the information about what is currently relevant for employers.‚†Äüìå Trend 1 - Remote or hybrid work format.Yes, it is still relevant and will be so for many more years. Companies that implement such a format of work have increasingly begun to take care of the emotional and mental health of their employees, which is successfully developing at their work outside the office.‚†Äüìå Trend 2 - The value of learning. Competition in the market pushes employers to stay afloat and train employees in new technologies, bringing their knowledge and skills up to current ideals.‚†Äüìå Trend 3 - Well-being programs for employees.This is now not just a benefit for the employee, but an opportunity for the employer to support him both in personal and professional spheres.‚†ÄOf course, ADABSTAR specialists can highlight to you the subtleties and nuances of certain spheres/companies and positions on the labor market, but as they say:"Who owns all the information, owns the world" üåç ‚úåüèªinstagram: @adabstar #work #career #opportunity #adabstar #startup #employee

In addition to the 5 ways to achieve career success, there is another, independent way. This is mentoring.‚†ÄA mentor is someone who can be a friend, advisor and support in one person:‚†Ä1. He gives a boost to both personal and professional growth through honest, feedback about you and your performance.2. He helps push the boundaries of your goals and gives you effective ways to achieve them.3. He doesn't take responsibility for your work, but gives it to you by keeping you on track.4. He develops your leadership skills and soft skills such as listening, compassion and support.5. He gives implicit knowledge and guidance for free, guiding mentees, unlocking their potential, and helping them overcome obstacles to career advancement.‚†ÄWorking with a mentor is life-changing because it helps you understand who you are and who you want to become. Although mentors are not therapists, they help develop the sense of awareness and discovery that only comes through conscious effort.‚†ÄYou too may someday want to share your experience with others, which will help you become a better leader yourself and give you a new perspective on life.https://adabstar.com #career #work #success #mentoring #adabstar #startup

Building a successful career means something different to everyone. For some it's fun, for others financial gain.  Regardless of what criteria you use to define a successful career, the important thing is that it is an interesting and exciting experience for everyone.‚†ÄTo achieve career success, keep in mind the following ways:‚†Äüí°Goals - think about what you want to accomplish and why. Write down your goals and revisit them as your career progresses. But remember that goals can change and that's okay.‚†Äüí°Action Plan - Develop a plan to achieve your goals.  Determine the anchor points for your goals and what steps will help you achieve them.‚†Äüí°Networking - make the most of it. Attend events, network with peers, develop relationships and your network of contacts.‚†Äüí°Your strengths - always be aware of them. Knowing your strengths can give you confidence in your job search and as you develop professionally.‚†Äüí°Growth mindset - try to develop this trait by asking yourself open-ended questions when faced with challenges at work. Everything can be learned if you put enough effort into learning it‚†ÄAnd if you haven't yet decided how to apply these ways to your practice, our experts can help you figure it out!https://adabstar.com #career #work #goals #adabstar #startup #networking #experience

We like to talk about careers and career development. And we also like to back it up with numbers and analysis.‚†ÄSo, for example, to understand the problem of career planning and why people turn to career professionals, we were able to find out that:‚†Ä1. According to UNESCO, by 2025 the number of students in the world will increase to 260 million.And that means new positions and competition in the marketplace.‚†Ä2. At the beginning of 2022 more than 39.7% of world population will change their profession during their life.And that means finding a new job, adapting their r√©sum√© and going through a dozen interviews.‚†Ä3. 26.6% of people want to get a more prestigious profession.And this means - the definition of the future profession at an early stage is a profitable investment in their future.‚†ÄAnd every year the % will increase.‚†ÄTherefore ADABSTAR urges to take care of yourself and your future now #job #career #careerdevelopment #people #students #future #adabstar #startup

Besides our work with schoolchildren, applicants and students, the ADABSTAR platform is also open to career development within Companies and the B2B sector.‚†ÄWe aim at solving corporate queries, where ADABSTAR specialists will help to point out areas for competence development, Hard and Soft skills of specialists and select the right tools for career development.‚†ÄTo be a competitive specialist not only within the company, but also on the international market.To maintain the image and reputation of the business, through openness and improvement of its employees.‚†ÄThis is what ADABSTAR + Business strives for #b2b #business #startup #adabstar #career #careerdevelopment

ADABSTAR is not only a platform for career professionals and people at the crossroads of their career path, but also a platform for the development of educational institutions and their community in the digital space üååüíª‚†ÄBy developing University/College status through our platform, we enable institutions to make themselves, their professionals, possible internships and internship destinations directly known, and to compete for the best faculty and applicants from around the world.‚†ÄADABSTAR is an opportunity to make a statement and to show prospective students that it is in their institution that one will invest their time.‚†ÄADABSTAR + education = confidence in your futureüë©üèæ‚Äçüéìüë®üèº‚Äçüéì#adabstar #career #opportunity #startup #educacion #hr #mentoring #onlineplatform

Choosing a profession and the future - this is what young people think about at age 16 or 18 ü§î‚†ÄHow do you choose what to do with your life in the future?‚†ÄTop 3 tips from the ADABSTAR team:‚†Ä1. Do what you really like to do. A job you love = the key to a happy person.‚†Ä2. Determine what talents and aptitudes you have.  If you love drawing and you're interested in everything that has to do with design - so choose the areas of this direction. Don't become an engineer if that's what your family wants.‚†Ä3. Set a goal for yourself and define your motivation. Want to become like Elon Musk or be a freelancer - all in your hands. Do your best and do the impossible.‚†ÄAnd if you still do not know where to invest your potential - experts ADABSTAR, represented by career counsellors and psychologists will direct you in the right direction!‚†ÄDare! üî•#team #career #future #motivation #people #adabstar #education #startup

Why do you think we created ADABSTAR?‚†ÄYes, globally we want to change everyone's life and help them find themselves and their career path.‚†ÄBut when we look at it in depth and point by point, we see that this is a huge problem which has to be dealt with as quickly as possible!‚†ÄHow do you write a resume? How do you get an interview? How do I go freelance? How do I figure out where to go to work after University? How not to go crazy from a job I don't like? How to get a job at Google? ....And many more HOWs.‚†ÄIt's because of "HOW?" that we created our platform.‚†Ä- We strive to cover the entire spectrum of career development, from school age on up.- We want to communicate to you that it's cool to do what you love.- We want to put a tool in your hands to help you plan your life anywhere in the world.- And, of course, we want to show you that realizing yourself is not as scary as you think, the main thing is to start doing it in time and in the right way.‚†ÄSo, we see a problem, we make a solution - the ADABSTAR platform. #job #career #university #careerdevelopment #startup #hrtech #hr

What is my post about?¬†For several months now, my team and I have been developing the ADABSTAR platform. ADABSTAR ("adapt before you start") is a career planning platform that helps people find career experts around the world to help you start a new profession or choose the best university and course of study for you, or finally change your hated job...For educational institutions, for example, we have the option of holding open lectures to interest potential applicants, scouting outstanding applicants. The option of open communication "without frames", an important component for the new generation, has been implemented.For business, there are options for communicating with the best of the best young professionals, whose rankings we will screen in our databank. Opportunities to collaborate with educational institutions and career influencers.By the way, we're creating a platform with social networking elements, where posts and video lectures will be posted, as well as webinars and any other online events.¬†See you in June 2022 https://adabstar.com¬†Any opinions are welcome, thank you for listening.#startup #education #job #students #relocation #career

The market is growing and is expected to grow to $397.6 billion by the end of 2025.Today, I would like to share some useful tips that companies should consider before making a deal with a vendor. On the one hand, these are very simple things that you have already heard or know, on the other hand, the lack of information provided below can cost you the failure of the project.‚Ä¢ Ask about company policy - ask as many questions as you want. This also applies to company policy. A lot of vendors are guided by their direction, which may differ from the vision of the client. The main idea is that the vendor has to meet customer expectations, be flexible, and be involved in the development of the customer‚Äôs product or service. Many companies act as executors, not partners, and build their strategy exclusively for a short period of time.‚Ä¢ Connect with a previous client - Most likely (if not exactly) you will choose among those companies that have some experience behind them. You always have the opportunity to contact previous clients with whom the vendor worked. Such information is always available either on the contractor‚Äôs website or on platforms like Clutch. By talking directly with a previous client, you can be sure to understand whether you should cooperate with the vendor or not. üë©‚ÄçüöÄ You may quickly produce and manage your digital content by using a Headless CMS and Decoupled Architecture.A headless content management system (CMS) is a back-end-only CMS that lets you create and manage the content that drives your digital platforms, like a website or mobile app, but does not offer a user interface (UI) to handle the material. Instead, it offers an API that enables you to use your own, independently developed UI to access the content that is kept in the CMS.Principal Advantages of Headless CMS‚úÖ Offers an API so that material can be accessed from any front-end interface.‚úÖ Enables the use of the same material across various platforms (website, mobile app, etc.)‚úÖ Offers more scalability and flexibility‚úÖ Focus on creating and delivering high-quality content‚úÖ Performance gains from Frontend decouplingYou may simplify and streamline your digital content management in several ways with the use of a headless content management system (CMS). Users can effortlessly create and maintain their digital material without worrying about how it will look on various platforms because it offers an API that enables you to access your content from any front-end interface. Since you can utilize the same material to power a website, mobile app, and other digital platforms, managing your online presence across several channels is made simpler. Furthermore, a headless CMS can provide more scalability and flexibility because it makes it simple to add new features and content without worrying about keeping up with user interface updates.My top picks as a Developer for the leading headless CMS currently on the market are listed below:1. Strapi: Rest API, GraphQL, Dynamic Components, Open SourceSite: strapi.ioGithub: https://lnkd.in/etwXA-vG2. Hasura: Rest API, GraphQL, Open SourceSite: hasura.ioGithub: https://lnkd.in/eTdGqCVW3. Directus: Rest API, GraphQL, Community Cloud Tier, Open SourceSite: directus.ioGithub: https://lnkd.in/eUuuxXNrA Comprehensive overview of headless CMS: https://lnkd.in/ecDDn234In conclusion, employing a headless CMS can greatly enhance the process of prototyping and developing apps. Developers may concentrate on creating the greatest user experience possible without having to worry about how the content will be shown by separating the content management system from the presentation layer. Top 5 Frontend Development Trends to Watch Out for in 2023Mobile First, SSG, SSR, NoCode, Serverless and Edge, WASM1. Mobile Comes First: Business Website Needs a Mobile-first ApproachPrioritizing the design and development of a website or web application for mobile devices before planning for desktop or larger screens is known as the "mobile first" strategy. This strategy is predicated on the notion that since most internet users now access the web through smartphones, it is crucial to optimize the user experience for these smaller screens.Pagespeed: pagespeed.web.dev2. Lightning Fast Landings: The Power of Static Site GenerationFast website loading times are vital because they enhance user experience, boost conversion rates, and can help with search engine rankings. By pre-generating static HTML files, which may be served to consumers more rapidly and with less overhead than dynamically generated pages, static site generators can aid in achieving exceptional website speed.Some popular SSG/SSR frameworks include:- nextjs.org- astro.build- gatsbyjs.com- nuxtjs.org- kit.svelte.dev3. The Future is Now: No Code RequiredNo-code platforms give users access to a set of tools, pre-built templates, and features that enable them to create and customize web applications and other sorts of projects without having to have a deep understanding of programming.There are several reasons why businesses may choose to use no-code platforms:- Rapid prototyping and testing.- Reduced development costs.- Faster development times.- Quicker time to market.- Increased agility.Here are a few no-code platforms that businesses may consider using:- Webflow- Bubble- Airtable- AppSheet- Retool4. Webapps Goes Full Throttle: The Power of Serverless and Edge ComputingTwo related cloud computing ideas that have gained popularity in recent years are serverless computing and edge computing. The performance, scalability, and cost-effectiveness of cloud-based applications and services can all be enhanced by combining these trends.Serverless: https://lnkd.in/ehj3aST7Edge Computing: https://lnkd.in/e_-QD2Xq5. Web AssemblyWebAssembly will alter web apps by enabling them to run quicker and more effectively in the browser, enabling the development of more sophisticated and potent web applications.webassembly.org---In conclusion, there will be a lot of exciting trends emerging in the frontend development industry in 2023. It's a wonderful moment to be a front-end developer, with advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning, the continuous use of JavaScript frameworks, and the development of webassembly. What further frontend development trends do you see being significant in 2023? Please share your thoughts and insights in the comments below.#computing #technology #javascript #frontend #developer #business #development #future #nocode

‚úÖ Consistently Structure Your Commits with Conventional Commitsconventionalcommits.orgResources:https://lnkd.in/eB65Ax_nAs a software architect, it is my responsibility to ensure that our software development team is following best practices in order to deliver high-quality, maintainable software. One best practice that I have found to be particularly useful is the use of Conventional Commits.Conventional Commits is a standardized way to write commit messages in a version control system like Git. It helps developers describe changes made in a consistent, structured format, making it easier for automated tools to interpret and use the messages.Conventional Commits provide a clear, structured format for commit messages with a type, scope, detailed body, and optional footer for automated tool interpretation.Some common types used in Conventional Commits include:- feat: a new feature- fix: a bug fix- chore: maintenance or infrastructure changes- docs: changes to documentation- style: formatting or style changes- refactor: code refactoring- perf: performance improvements- test: additions, changes, or improvements to tests- revert: revert a previous commitUsing Conventional Commits in commercial projects can be beneficial for a number of reasons. Here are a few:1. Consistency: By following a standard format for commit messages, all team members can write commit messages in a consistent style, which can make it easier to read and understand commit history.2. Automation: Tools like Semantic Release can use Conventional Commits to automatically interpret commit messages and streamline release processes, saving time and effort for developers.3. Improved documentation: Commit messages written in the Conventional Commits format provide a clear and concise summary of the changes made in each commit. This can make it easier to understand the history of a project and track down specific changes.4. Improved collaboration: Following a standardized commit message format makes it simpler for team members to comprehend and evaluate one another's work, enhancing teamwork and the project's overall quality.5. Enhanced project management: Conventional Commits give project managers and stakeholders a clear, organized perspective of project progress and changes, which helps them stay updated, particularly in large or lengthy projects.Overall, the use of Conventional Commits can be a valuable tool for any software development team.What's your secret to success when it comes to collaborating on commits with a team or working with them solo?#softwaredevelopment¬†#software¬†#softwareengineering¬†#team¬†#project¬†#automation¬†#work¬†#projects¬†#infrastructure¬†#architect¬†#like¬†#quality¬†#teamwork¬†#collaboration¬†#projectmanagement¬†#maintenance¬†#projectmanagers¬†#success¬†#help¬†#frontenddeveloper¬†#backenddeveloper¬†#github¬†#gitlab¬†#python¬†#typescript¬†#golang¬†#javascript

Major tech companies such as Google, Microsoft and American chipmaker Qualcomm have opposed NVIDIA's $40 billion acquisition of British chipmaker Arm, Bloomberg News reported.  CNBC notes that Qualcomm has told regulators around the world that it openly opposes the deal. 	In the event of a deal, NVIDIA will gain control of an important vendor that licenses core chip technologies to companies such as Apple, Intel, Samsung, Amazon and China's Huawei. 	The British Arm is known as the Switzerland of the industry, as it is who issues licenses for the development of microcircuits and the corresponding program code to everyone. 	Fierce opposition to the deal from large tech companies could make it difficult for NVIDIA to get regulatory approval. The company could also be forced to make concessions on the terms of the deal, which would change Arm's value to NVIDIA.  #PixelTj #news #business

Unlocking the Secrets to Business Success: Lessons from Warren BuffettWarren Buffett, the legendary investor and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, has become a household name in the business world. With a net worth of over $100 billion, Buffett's success has been attributed to his unique investment strategy and business acumen. In this article, we will explore some of the lessons that business owners and entrepreneurs can learn from Warren Buffett to help them achieve success in their own ventures.Make a Unique ContributionWarren Buffett is known for investing in companies that make a unique contribution to their industry or have a competitive advantage. Business owners should also strive to make a unique contribution and find a way to differentiate themselves from their competitors.Think Long-TermBuffett has always been a proponent of long-term investing, often holding onto his investments for decades. Business owners should also focus on long-term strategies and avoid short-term thinking that may sacrifice long-term growth and stability.Invest in What You UnderstandBuffett famously invests only in businesses that he understands. Business owners should also invest in what they understand and avoid investing in industries or businesses they don't fully comprehend.Don't Be Afraid to Make MistakesBuffett has made mistakes in the past, but he has always learned from them and improved his approach. Business owners should also not be afraid to make mistakes, as they can provide valuable lessons for future projects.Make Informed DecisionsBuffett always makes informed and rational decisions, analyzing financial data and forecasting potential returns. Business owners should also make decisions based on facts and analysis, rather than intuition and emotions.Build Your BrandWarren Buffett is a well-known business figure and personality. He knows how to create a unique brand and use it to achieve success. Business owners should also know how to promote their brand and create a positive impression on their customers and partners.Never Stop LearningWarren Buffett is always eager to learn and improve his knowledge. He often reads books and attends seminars and conferences to stay up-to-date on investment trends. Business owners should also constantly strive to improve their skills and knowledge.In conclusion, Warren Buffett's lessons can be valuable for any business owner or entrepreneur striving for success. It's important to make a unique contribution, focus on long-term strategies, invest in what you understand, not be afraid to make mistakes, make informed decisions, build your brand, and never stop learning. By following these tips, you can achieve great success in your business and investments.#business #data #success #entrepreneur #growth #future #learning #strategy #investment #help #brand #entrepreneurs #investing #ceo #projects #investments #businessowners

A Woman's Experience of Interviewing with her Husband as the HR SpecialistMary had been a successful businesswoman and was often away on business trips due to her work commitments. As a result, she and her husband Leo stopped finding time for each other and their relationship began to deteriorate. But neither of them expected their paths to cross again in such an unusual place as an interview.For the first few minutes, they tried to conduct themselves professionally, but when Leo began to ask non-standard questions, the tension began to build. Eventually, Mary couldn't take it anymore and responded to Leo's question about what had been holding her back from being successful for the last ten years by pointing to his mother. This led to an argument, and Leo decided to reject his wife's application for the job in the company.However, Leo had overlooked an important factor - Mary was a true professional and knew how to present herself in the best light in any situation. She decided not to give up and requested a second interview with another HR specialist. In her second interview, Mary demonstrated her best qualities, showcasing the skills and knowledge that had helped her succeed in her previous work.When the company learned about what had happened, they gave Leo a warning for displaying emotions during the interview and not adhering to the criteria of neutrality for an HR specialist. In the end, Mary was hired as an executive director, and Leo was fired from the company.This story shows how important it is to maintain a professional approach to work, even if you encounter someone with whom you have had personal problems. It is also important to understand that HR specialists must maintain neutrality and not display emotions, even if it is difficult for them. Ultimately, a worker's professional qualities and experience should be the main criteria.#business #hr #work #experience #interviewing #interview #job

How to deal with difficult clientsProbably everyone has met such clients, and if not, then you will meet them. Which clients are considered problematic:üìç They don‚Äôt know what result they want to get, but at the same time they tend to blame others for their mistakes; üìç Unwilling to respect the agreements;üìç Each question begins with ‚Äúyour program doesn‚Äôt work!‚Äù, and in 90% of cases it turns out that the client either does not understand how it should work or uses it incorrectly;üìç He thinks he knows better how you should work, etc.Why should you work with them? Firstly, you can't always identify it from the first meeting. Secondly, not every business can afford to refuse profits due to the difficult client, because each project will be important for business growth.- With such clients, you should move the communication and correspondence into a controlled channel. If you are discussing issues on the phone or at a meeting, then it will be difficult to check the history of communication, and prove that you said this and not otherwise.- Be very attentive: to the advice that you give, the messages that you write, to the deadlines that you set. Therefore meeting the deadlines, in this case, should be compulsory. And to be watertight you must work strictly according to the written agreements that you have with the client. If you screw up somewhere, the client will use this opportunity to make claims against you, whether reputational or financial.- Sign papers. Yes, you can't do without bureaucracy. Each completed functionality and development stage must be closed by an act where the client signs that he has accepted and has no complaints. Keep a close eye on the reports, and do not start new work while there are unfinished ones.You can also learn more with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr #projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#experience¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#skills¬†#work¬†#business¬†#learning¬†#team¬†#communication¬†#management¬†#communicationskills¬†#tips #clients

Communication with the client: 5 tips on how not to do itWhen communicating with a client, the price of a mistake can be too high. In this post, I want to share with you tips on what not to do if you want to create a successful communication with a client.üìç Do not answer the client's question concisely. All messages to clients should contain answers to the questions ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWho?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù. That is, ‚ÄúWhat will be fulfilled‚Äù, ‚ÄúWho will carry it out and for how long‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhen it will be done‚Äù. This adds transparency to communication with clients.üìç Please, never answer ‚ÄúThe client wants so‚Äù to either the team members or the management when they ask you ‚ÄúWhy are we doing such nonsense?‚Äù.¬†¬†You have to understand why the client wants it that way, and why he needs it. You should discuss with the client that his goal can be reached in a different way, perhaps it is faster, cheaper and better for the result.üìç If you resolve an issue or fix a bug with a specialist during communication with a client, and you urgently need to leave, do not leave the client alone with the specialist. Often the client begins to overload the specialist with his wishes, which you didn‚Äôt estimate, but the performer doesn‚Äôt know about this and begins to do it.üìç If you don‚Äôt want to sort out the certification of statements and any other documents with the client later, don‚Äôt send the document for certification with a link to Google Drive. The text of documents on Google Drive can be changed and so you can waste time trying to prove with a history of changes that it was different text at the time of certification.üìç Wait until the client asks ‚ÄúWhat is the situation on the project?‚Äù. It is better to inform the client once a week about the status of the project, so you will have a point of control and the client will not bother you once again. Design Fundamentals for Project/Product Managers: Gestalt in DesignDesign fundamentals or a general understanding of it will be a big plus in your work. Today I will talk about gestalt in design.Gestalt (‚Äúform‚Äù in German) is a group of visual perception principles developed by German psychologists in the 1920s. It is based on the theory that "an organized whole is perceived greater than the sum of its parts". These principles are used in the design of user interfaces.Gestalt principles in design:1) ProximityElements that are closely spaced are perceived as more connected ones than those that are farther apart. Thus, various elements can be viewed as a group and not individually.2) Common regionSimilar to the principle of proximity, elements located in the same closed area are perceived as grouped.3) SimilarityElements with similar visual characteristics are perceived as more connected than those that do not have similar features.4) SymmetrySymmetrical elements tend to be perceived as belonging to each other, regardless of the distance between them, and giving us a sense of wholeness and order.5) The principle of continuationElements arranged in a line or on a smooth curve are perceived as more connected than randomly ordered ones.User interface design isn't all about colourful pixels and flashy graphics. Basically, it is communication, efficiency and convenience. Gestalt principles are always relevant; they help create the conditions for a pleasant user experience and business success.You can also learn more on the topic with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#team¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#skills¬†#work¬†#business¬†#design #interfacedesign #communication #userexperience #gestalt

IT project manager and system administration issues: about complex in a simple way When you plan the project, arises the question of where the project will be developed. It can be a client's internal server, a rented server, your company's server, or a local developer's machine (not the best option, of course). Even if your company does not provide hosting or system administration services, your software is often inextricably linked and depends on server capacity and software that is installed on those servers. Here are a few things you should pay attention to:- you should ask the programmers about the technical requirements of the project in advance and decide who will set up the server;- inform the system administrator if you need to deploy a mail server, organize remote desktops for employees or print documents on local computers from the software installed on the server;- discuss the need to purchase licensed packages for the software used or the possibility of solving project tasks with free software;- it is important to discuss the issue of further maintenance of servers with the client because they often think that ‚Äúyou're the programmer‚Äù, and so you will take it upon yourself, and they don‚Äôt really understand why these works cost extra money.Also, the choice of the server depends on the localization of its users. If the service will work in the German market, you should not buy a server in the US or Russia, because the speed of work for users will be smaller due to the time required to transfer traffic.You can also learn more on the topic with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#team¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#skills¬†#work¬†#business #maintenance #software

Lean project management: how does it work? This approach forms a philosophy of lean thinking and allows you to save resources and get the best result. If we use a primitive interpretation, then if the process can be done faster and cheaper, it should be done right now.The Lean concept comes from the industry. It was first implemented by Toyota to reduce losses and bring the product closer to consumer expectations. In the context of IT, we can say that the main purpose of the Lean approach is to eliminate waste.Which of the Lean approach rules can be applied to the IT industry?- Reduce losses. Analyze processes, if some actions do not bring profit, but waste the developer's time ‚Äì give up on them.- Don‚Äôt forget about learning. If you want to make a high-quality project, it is necessary to constantly improve your and your team's knowledge and skills.- Get a response as soon as possible. Reduce response delays whenever possible. The sooner the team shows its work to the client, the sooner you will receive feedback from him. You can also optimize the redundant approval process.- Monitor the process. At each stage, keep in mind the goal you want to achieve. Also, for smoothly running work, each member of the team has to understand the tasks and be able to see the process as a whole.The purpose of any business is to create value, and the value of a product is determined by consumers. The goal of Lean is to optimize the production or development process in such a way as to create value while reducing costs.You can also learn more on the topic with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#team¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#skills¬†#work #business #lean #learning

Project Management Principles from ‚ÄúCritical Chain‚Äù by Eliyahu Goldratt I want to share with you this book; after reading it you will change your view of the project management you are used to. Here I will briefly outline the basic principles of project management described in the book.1) The project deadline is the length of the critical path + the project buffer at the end of the path. In the book, attention is paid to the fact that in traditional project management, insuring is laid in each element of the critical path. And it averages about 200%.In accordance with the theory of the Critical Chain, insuring should go at the end of the path so that the deadlines for completing the elements of the critical path do not increase. The increase in the timing with insuring in each element of the path comes from our psychology: being oriented on the deadline of the delivery of an element, we do everything at the last moment, and then miss the deadlines.2) Feeding buffers should be made at the injection points of the supply paths into the critical path. They will help us level out the delays on the supply paths without increasing the duration of the project itself.3) Project progress should only be measured on the critical path. In this case, it is also necessary to monitor the state of the buffer on the supply paths.4) When planning the timing of the project, it is necessary to take into account the competition for resources. Therefore, you need to carefully plan the schedule of the busiest resources.5) Time during the project is lost due to: multitasking (when switching from task to task, 75% of the time is lost), the habit of postponing everything until the deadline (student syndrome), Parkinson's law (i.e. the habit of meeting deadlines, even if the task takes much less time) and loss of priorities (when we start paying attention to items not on the critical path). 6) Any improvements NOT in the weak unit of the project do not make sense. You should work only on the bottlenecks of the project. And do not touch what works so well.You can also learn more with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#team¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#skills¬†#work #planning #books

Agile: Scrum and Kanban differencesMost likely, you have already met the definitions and similarities, so I want to describe the differences in this post.An important point: agile methodology is a philosophy of an agile approach to development when Kanban and Scrum are methodologies of this philosophy. We apply them depending on the tasks.Scrum is based on short, 2-3 week sprints. Before the start of the sprint, the team generates a list of tasks for the iteration, and then the sprint starts. After the end of the sprint, completed tasks are uploaded to production, and uncompleted ones are transferred to another sprint. As a rule, the tasks done during the sprint do not change: what was at the start of the sprint must be done at any cost by the end of the sprint. In Scrum, you should evaluate tasks in Story points or hours. Without evaluation, it will not be possible to form a sprint: after all, we need to know if we will manage to complete the tasks in 2 weeks.Kanban gives you more flexibility if you define by it the frequency with which priorities change. If yesterday the developer uploaded the completed task, and today they received data and found out that this thing does not work as intended, they give new requirements. Added new tasks rise up, and the programmer takes this task "from above", executes it, and, by the evening, everything works as it should. Everyone is happy and effective more than ever. In Kanban, you don‚Äôt evaluate. There is no concept of ‚Äúteamwork speed‚Äù here, only the average time per task is considered.So, in Scrum, our goal is to finish the sprint; in Kanban, we complete the task.Scrum requires fixed roles, while Kanban doesn‚Äôt have them. Scrum is based on iterations, combining planning, process optimization and release. In Kanban, this can be done regularly or whenever you need to. The Scrum team requires evaluation of their work, while the Kanban team doesn‚Äôt.You can also learn more on the topic with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#team¬†#development¬†#it¬†#project¬†#tools¬†#teamwork¬†#work¬†#management #data #kanban #agile #scrum #planning

Project, product, program, and delivery manager: understand the concepts once and for all In fact, the differences are described in the terms themselves, but despite this, confusion still occurs :) So what is the responsibility of these specialists?- Project manager is someone who receives a task from a client and transfers it to specialists. He is the project coordinator and is responsible for meeting deadlines. After the verification, he delivers the finished product to the client.- Product manager controls not the development of functionality but the testing of hypotheses and the development of the product; there is more marketing here. It means he analyzes what is interesting to the client and makes suggestions for product development.To make it easier, we can identify that the product manager is responsible for the product, and the project manager is responsible for the process.- Program manager manages the program, which includes several projects and teams. When the project is complex and large, there is a need for the participation of a team consisting of several projects. The program manager coordinates and manages such a team or teams.- Delivery manager. This term appeared not so long ago. This person is responsible in the project for delivering the result to the customer within all constraints (such as budget, deadlines, quality, and risks). The delivery manager position requires deep diving into technology, architecture, products, and management. He is responsible for ensuring that, as part of the combined action of all the above (and not only) roles, the client receives the result that allows him to achieve his goals.All of these roles serve an essential function in any high-performing team :)¬†You can also learn more with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr #projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach #team #development #productmanager #deliverymanager #it #project

When we speak about IT project management, it is impossible not to mention the risks. Let's talk about those that we most often deal with in our work:üìç the performer got sick or quit,üìç there were technical difficulties during the implementation,üìç the client delayed with decisions or providing information that is necessary to continue the project and so on.I advise you to write down the most common problems you deal with and think about their solutions before starting the project.If this happens, team members should have clear guidelines on how to proceed. Knowing how to work on long timelines is also important in dealing with crisis management. Subcontractors or your employees may let you down, or the client may delay some information without which you cannot continue the work.By the way, it is essential to foresee in the contract how you should act in this case, whether there will be any penalty that the client owes you for not providing information on time. In this case, you must immediately inform the client that the deadlines will be shifted if you do not receive the information on time.If you do not make it just to be safe in the progress of the project, then the client will have complaints against you during the handover. But, if the timelines are already prolonged, then full alert status comes. You should start by making a to-do list and prioritizing whenever you have limited time. Give priority to those tasks that cause the most damage to the client or that the client knows about.There is no project without risks; the key point here is their constant monitoring and before-the-fact prevention. Top 5 Mistakes of IT Project Managers and How to Avoid Them  In about ten years of managing a team of project managers, I have identified the most common mistakes. So, I want to share this experience with you and, perhaps, save a hundred other projects that were destined to fail)Mistake 1: ‚ÄúEverything will be fine.‚Äù‚ÄúI think we will meet the project deadline without laying the buffer on the execution period‚Äù, - I often hear from managers. Or: ‚ÄúWhat can go wrong?‚Äù You should expect that the client can delay design assurance, cannot provide the required information on time, etc.Mistake 2: ‚ÄúI have a good relationship with the client.‚ÄùIt would help if you did not hope that you can neglect preliminary assurances, document execution and agreement on new deadlines against the client's signature because you are on friendly terms with him. It is necessary to keep your back covered with a document or at least with a confirmation by mail at each addition to the technical requirement; otherwise, you will not ‚Äúbrush it off‚Äù later.Mistake 3: ‚ÄúThe client approved the project documentation with no issues.‚ÄùThis is a red flag. Most likely, this means that the client did not understand it and did not ask questions because he was embarrassed to admit it. But the problem is that he will poke you in the face with this expertise when he sees a product unlike the one ‚Äúin his head‚Äù. Mistake 4: ‚ÄúI did as the client asked‚ÄùUsually, this is the answer of the project manager when someone makes claims about really idiotic decisions in the project. And this argument is terrible, never use it. Thus you show your incompetence. Better just say you screwed up.Mistake 5: ‚ÄúWhat was the problem? I‚Äôll check with the programmer.‚ÄùThere is nothing shameful in the fact that you consult with a specialist before saying something to a client. Another issue is if we are talking about correcting an error and you inform the client about its correction without understanding the reasons in detail.The article's material is taken from the course on Udemy for project managers https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr #projectmanagers #team #experience #mistakes #projectmanagement¬†#projectmanager¬†#projectmanagerit¬†#projectmanagementcoach¬†#projectleader¬†#work¬†#projects¬†#it #commonmistakes

They tell you: ‚ÄúI need a carton of milk by tonight.‚Äù¬†‚úÖBuy it by 20:00 today.‚úÖ Buy it in a store near the house.‚úÖ Fat content 2.5%.‚úÖ Milk should be pasteurized.What would a simple commitment look like without essential details?They would say, "Please buy some milk on the way home."In the second case, neither the characteristics nor the time is indicated to us. Hands-on approach or how to prevent problems with performers  How to communicate properly with the performer in order not to miss possible problems at work? I want to recommend the ‚Äúhands-on‚Äù approach.Using this approach, you need to control what exactly people are doing at each stage of work; otherwise, due to the ‚Äúcontext-free management‚Äù, the specialist may misunderstand the task and may spend a lot of time on it, so he is not in time, and it‚Äôs your fault because you didn‚Äôt control what he was doing. In this case, claims will be specifically on the project manager and not just on the specialist: why didn‚Äôt he control and stop the performer earlier, why didn‚Äôt he understand that the specialist was doing the wrong thing. To avoid context-free management, you need to ask targeted questions. It is clear that it is easier to ask ‚Äúdid you do it?‚Äù and get the answer ‚Äúyes, I did‚Äù. But in reality, this approach will bring you many unexpected problems during commissioning. If you ask a few clarifying questions about the logic and implementation technologies or dig deeper into the smallest details in one particular task that you feel is problematic, you can find many important errors, so it will help you not blush in front of the client during commissioning.  If you do not understand the essence of the task, the chances are high that it will be completed incorrectly. When answering clarifying questions, you can reveal either that the person is lying or that he did not take into account something and got confused.Therefore, feel free to ask clarifying questions; you do not look stupid because of this. So it will be clear to the interlocutor, especially when in this way you will find his mistake.You also can learn more with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projects #projectmanagement #it #approaches #projectmanager #communication #work #management #project

What technical skills does a project manager need?IT project manager is a person who combines both analytical and technical skills. However, it is worth noting that these qualities are not considered mandatory, but they will help you a lot in your work.HTML/CSS - HTML is a hypertext markup language. CSS is a style description language. It describes the appearance of HTML elements. If you plan to work in development, then these skills will come useful.Basic programming functions. Here the programming language does not matter. It is necessary to have an understanding at the level of standard functions: if, then, start/stop. sort, etc. So it will be easier for you to read the specialists‚Äô code and even suggest solutions during the brainstorming process.The basics of mechanical and automated testing (QA). Here you will need knowledge at the level of testing types in order to understand how automated testing services are configured. You don't need to know how to set it up individually. Types of document formatting. Here you need to know what types of formats exist for: text documents (TXT, RTF, DOC, DOCX, HTML, PDF), images (RAW, JPEG,TIFF,PSD,PNG) and video files (MP4,M4P,MOV,MKV ). It is also desirable to understand how they differ from each other and how to convert one format to another.Basic design skills. For web development or for those projects where the design is used, you will need skills such as: unload icons from design in photoshop layers, look at the type of font or check the RGB color code. It will also be useful to be able to compare the design with the pixel perfect layout.Basic knowledge in system administration. In this case, the required knowledge depends on the type of manageable projects. I will only note that here you need to understand the types of hosting, how the server is configured, what software is responsible for what, what logs are available and how the mail is working at the mail server.Any skills (hard or soft skills), are best developed through practice. And if you want to make it easier to move from theory to practice, you can learn more with my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#work #development #projectmanagement #projectmanager #IT #itprojectmanagement #skills #itprojects #hardskills

4 principles of effective team communication The success of each project directly depends on the team and its specialists. They are the participants of the project work with whom you constantly have to communicate. The best way is to start selecting and forming a team before you start the work. Even if you have such people, it is better to clarify their employment status and inform them about the time when the project is planned to be executed. It is necessary to do, so that they plan their work according to it. Regardless of whether you work with full-time or freelance professionals, I advise you to pay attention to such things as: - work exclusively by preliminary budgeting;- if you don't want to lose people during the project, you should monitor the mood of each team member and in advance raise the conversation about the reasons for a bad mood, exceeded timeframes and negative statements;- welcome the initiative in the team. It's good when you have such an atmosphere in your team in which any person can offer his own solution to the problem, and he will not be thrown with rotten tomatoes;- improve your technical literacy and speak with programmers in their language.Excellent results will be obtained only with well-coordinated and harmonized work of the entire team.I paid a special attention to the work with performers in my course materials where you can learn more https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#projectmanagement #projectmanager #it #itprojects #itprojectmanagement #teamwork #projectleader #management #team #communication

Work/life balance or life as the most important project  Very often managers forget that in addition to the projects that they do for clients, there are no less, but rather more important ones. These projects include: your family, relationships with friends or a hobby that brings you joy and make you feel the fullness of life. There are also some resources in your life that you use, deadlines that are important to fit in, and KPI metrics.The fact, that in the IT field people often work overtime, is not new. It is a big advantage that IT specialists can work wherever there is the Internet, but it also their divine judgment. After all, projects work 24/7, but such a schedule is difficult for people. It is important to monitor your condition and not drive yourself to the point of burnout. Rest should not be taken as a deadtime, but as a revival.I want to share a technique that helps you prioritize correctly and save yourself from projects and tasks that steal your time without bringing enough profit. I resort to it every time I notice that I start to work overtime systematically. It can be compared to clearing the closet of unnecessary things that fill the space. So you need to:- monitor where your time goes by keeping a calendar;- make an analysis of the distribution of your time on projects for a calendar month;- evaluate your projects in terms of benefits (profit, experience, self-realization) that you can get from them in relation to the time you spend on them;- cut off all that you don't need. If the project takes up most of your time, despite the fact that its benefit to you is insignificant, then you should not be afraid to part with it.It is rightly said that ‚Äúthere‚Äôs always more fish in the sea‚Äù, but the time spent with loved ones as well as your physical and mental health is priceless. Life time is limited and at the end of your life you will be ready to buy this time for any money.Have you experienced burnout and how did you deal with it? Share your experience in the comments to the post, for all those who now want to find a way out of constant overtime work.#work #mentalhealth #experience #project #projectmanagement #itprojectmanagement #balance #worklife #management

What is Hybrid Project Management? Earlier, in my posts, I shared information about development methods. Today I want to touch on such a topic as a hybrid approach.Waterfall methodology allows you to predict the work plan and project timeframe. But the sequential execution of stages requires a lot of time, which, as always, is not enough and the project must be launched as quickly as possible. This is how the hybrid Waterfall was invented. Here the sequence of only critically interconnected processes is observed, and some of the development stages are parallel. This approach to development is currently considered the most effective by the American Project Management Institute (PMI), because it allows you to save time and is also well predicted. So, for example, after the project documentation, we can start programming while the design and layout are being developed. After the layout is ready, it will be combined with the developed functionality, giving it a design certified with the client. It saves a lot of project time, but it also contains potential problems. Such a development process is much more dependent on the discipline of the project manager, because if you miss changes in the process of working on the front, you can then spend a lot of time on finalizing the backend. Hybrid approach will give you the ability to combine methodologies and create new, more effective methods suited to specific projects.Which of the methodologies do you prefer in your work?You can learn more from my course https://lnkd.in/dYiS_jVr#development #projectmanagement #projectmanager #projectmanagerit #projectmanagementcoach #projectleader #it #management #projects
